newsitem.title: USA: U S West says Internet use may require price hikes.
newsitem.headline: U S West says Internet use may require price hikes.

text.p: Executives of regional phone company U S West Communications Group told state lawmakers Thursday that price hikes are the only way to reduce telephone system congestion caused by increasing use of the Internet.

Lobbyists for computer industry giants, including Microsoft Corp as well as consumer groups, immediately charged that U S West has only itself to blame for service problems. They also disputed that Internet users are overloading the phone network.

In recent months, some U S West customers in Washington's larger cities such as Seattle and Spokane have encountered constant busy signals or heard a recorded message saying "all circuits are busy" when attempting local calls.
The company blames the problem in part on flat rate-unlimited service offers by Internet service providers such as America Online Inc.
U S West says customers, who pay a flat monthly rate for local telephone service, are leaving their computers online for hours at a time, tying up valuable phone lines.
U S West corporate counsel Edward Shaw told a Washington state Senate panel the company cannot build its way out of the problem.
"We don't have that much money," he said.
The answer therefore is price incentives, said Shaw, who outlined a sliding scale pricing scheme.

"Consumers should have a flat rate for a reasonable amount of voice traffic, and that could be very generous," he said, offering $10 for 20 hours of service per month as a possibility. "But if you're going to hook your computer up and use more than that, you should pay an increment."
Computer industry representatives asserted that Internet usage cannot be blamed for crippling the public phone network.
"We haven't had a system that evolved enough to keep up with us," said American Electronics Association lobbyist Ian MacGowan.
He urged legislators to maintain pressure on the phone company to invest in its infrastructure.

Microsoft state government affairs director Deborah Brunton cited an industry-commissioned study that said the growth of the Internet has provided additional revenue to phone companies as customers purchase additional lines and enhanced services.
"The additional revenues have exceeded the increased costs from the growth of these services by a factor of greater than five to one," Brunton testified.
A measure before the Washington Senate Energy and Utilities Committee would prohibit mandatory measured service such as U S West is proposing.
The committee chairman, Republican Sen. Bill Finkbeiner, said he believes the measure has the votes to pass.
U S West Communications provides local phone service across 14 Western states.
